Michele Merkin poses in a bikini]] A 'bikini' is a type of women's two-piece
 swimsuit designed to provide minimal coverage of the body. One part of the
 attire covers the breasts and the other part covers the groin and part of or
 the entire buttocks, leaving an uncovered area between the two.

[[MerriamâWebster]] describe the bikini as "a woman's scanty two-piece bathing
suit" or "a man's brief swimsuit." It is
often worn in hot weather, while swimming or sunbathing. The shapes of both
parts of a bikini resemble women's underwear, and the lower part can range from
revealing thong or g-string to briefs.

In 1946, the term bikini was coined by Louis RÃ©ard, who
named the swimsuit after Bikini Atoll, where testing on the atomic bomb took place.
Reard chose the name bikini because he believed the suit's revealing style would
create a stir among people similar to their shock and surprise in response to
Americaâs atomic bombing of Japan the previous summer. [http://www.swimsuit-
style.com/bikini.html Swimsuit Trivia â The Surprising History of the Bikini].
Swimsuit-style.com. Retrieved on 2011-12-03.

The bikini is perhaps the most popular type of female beachwear around the
globe, according to French fashion historian Olivier Saillard due to "the power
of women, and not the power of fashion". As he explains, "The emancipation of
swimwear has always been linked to the emancipation of women." Kathryn Westcott, "[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/5130460.stm
The Bikini: Not a brief affair]", BBC News, 2006-06-05 By the mid-2000s,
bikinis had become a $811 million business annually, according to the NPD Group,
a consumer and retail information company. Sylvia Rubin, "[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-
bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2006/07/02/BIKINI.TMP&type=printable Fashion shocker
of '46: the naked belly button]", [[San Francisco Chronicle]], 2006-07-02
